skills.name: Letters 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
NEW USERS AND PEOPLE NEW TO HEBREW: See [here](https://duolinguists.wordpress.com/typing-in-hebrew-learn) for quick instructions on **typing** and **learning to read** Hebrew.

Welcome to the Hebrew course!
------------------

**Please read the Tips and Notes. They will help you understand how the Hebrew language works and will prevent misunderstandings. There is a lot to take in at the beginning, but don't be put off reading the notes. Stick with it, because they get shorter the further down the tree you go.**

We are very excited that you have chosen to learn Hebrew.
Remember that you can access the Tips and Notes from a lesson at any time by clicking the top-left corner, or by clicking the lightbulb if you are using Duolingo with skill levels enabled.

Before we get started, just be aware that the Hebrew language is written from ***right to left!***

![](http://imgur.com/qOMGBjM.png?1)

--------
The Hebrew Alphabet
--------

In Hebrew there are 22 letters, some of their sounds exist in English and some don't. A few letters have an ending form - that means that those letters look different when written at the end of a word (their pronunciation **does not change**).

Each letter is given with the pronunciation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) and a close-matching example in English:

(Letters in blue{@style=color:blue} are taught in this skill)

Name|Letter|Ending form|IPA|English example
---|---|---|---|---
Aleph {@style=color:blue}|| |//|**uh** (usually silent or similar to the letter "a" in English: a placeholder for vowels)**
Bet {@style=color:blue}|| |/b/*,/v/|bet, vet
Gimel|| |/g/|**g**o
Dalet|| |/d/|**d**og
Hey{@style=color:blue}|| |/h/|**h**en (often silent in modern colloquial speech)
Vav{@style=color:blue}|| |/v/|**v**et
Zayin|| |/z/|**z**oo
Chet{@style=color:blue}|| |/X/|lo**ch**
Tet|| |/t/| **t**en
Yod{@style=color:blue}|| |/j/|**y**es
Kaf|||/k/*, /X/|**c**at, lo**ch**
Lamed{@style=color:blue}|| |/l/|**l**og
Mem{@style=color:blue}|||/m/|**m**an
Nun{@style=color:blue}|||/n/|**n**o
Samekh|| |/s/|**s**ee
Ayin|| |//, //|**uh** |identical to  for most modern native Hebrew speakers
Pei|||/p/*,/f/|**p**ay, **f**ool
Tsadi|||/ts/|ca**ts**
Qof|| |/k/|**c**at
Resh|| |//|**r**un (similar to the French r)
Shin|| |//,/s/|**sh**e, **s**ee
Tav{@style=color:blue}|| |/t/|**t**ap

*These sounds are pronounced only when the letter is at the beginning of the word or at the beginning of a syllable. Otherwise, the other sound is usually the one that is pronounced.

**A common example for the use of "" as a silent letter is the word  (/lo/), which means "no".

----------------
The letter "vav" ()
----------------
The basic sound of the letter "vav" is "v".
However, it is also used in Hebrew as the vowel "u" and "o".

For example: 

* **** = (**o**hev).

* **** = (h**u**).

----------------
Articles
----------------
Hebrew has only a definite article (*i.e. "the"*).
This means that there are no indefinite articles (i.e. "a/an").
In order to add the definite article to a noun we simply attach the letter  to the beginning of the noun.

For example: 

 - boy/a boy (*yled*)

 =  +  - the boy (the "" as a definite article is pronounced  *Ha* - i.e. **ha**yled).

(Throughout the notes we add accents [like these: ] merely to show which syllable is stressed. In this case **ye**led and not ye**led**)

----------------
Connecting words
----------------
In order to connect words in Hebrew using the word "and", we attach the letter **** (vav) to the beginning of the second word.
When using it to connect words, the letter **** will usually sound like "ve".

For example:

 - a girl ( *yalda*)

  =   +  - a girl and a boy (yalda **ve**yeled)

We can also use both **** and **** together  ("the" and "and"):

 =  +  +  - **and the** boy (**ve-ha**-yeled)

----------------
Yes/No questions
----------------

Yes/No questions in Hebrew do not change the sentence structure. You can simply add a question mark in writing, and in speech, you can use a questioning intonation. 

For example:

>   (an ba) - I am a father.

> ?  (an ba?) - Am I a father?

We can also add the word "" (ha-m) in order to emphasize that a question is being asked, but it is considered formal, and is therefore not very common in spoken Hebrew.

For example:

>   (an ba) - I am a father.

> ?   (ha-m an ba?) - Am I a father?

-------------
The verbs "" and ""
-------------

In this lesson we come across our first two verbs -  (to come) and  (to love/like).
We are not going to teach verb conjugation yet, but just to clarify what we're dealing with:

 (ba) - "comes" for singular *masculine* nouns.

 (ba'a) - "comes" for singular *feminine* nouns.

-----------------------------------
 (ohv) - "loves/likes" for singular *masculine* nouns.

 (ohvet) - "loves/likes" for singular *feminine* nouns.

Gimel{@style=color:blue}|| |/g/|**g**o
Dalet{@style=color:blue}|| |/d/|**d**og
Hey{@style=color:green}|| |/h/|**h**en (often silent in modern colloquial speech)
Vav{@style=color:green}|| |/v/|**v**et
Zayin{@style=color:blue}|| |/z/|**z**oo
Chet{@style=color:green}|| |/X/|lo**ch**
Tet|| |/t/| **t**en
Yod{@style=color:green}|| |/j/|**y**es
Kaf{@style=color:blue}|||/k/*, /X/|**c**at, lo**ch**
Lamed{@style=color:green}|| |/l/|**l**og

*These sounds are pronounced only when the letter is at the beginning of the word or at the beginning of a syllable. Otherwise, the other sound will be the one that is pronounced.

**A common example for the use of "" as a silent letter is the word:  (/lo/) - which means "no".

-------------
The Hebrew Vowels
------------
In Hebrew the vowels aren't represented by letters, but by dots and dashes that appear around the letters. These dots and dashes are called nekudot (), and the system that they make up is known as nikud (). (Note: a common mistake for beginners is to refer to them as nikudot. This word doesn't exist.) Nikud isn't used much in modern Hebrew so we will learn how to read without it (see Letters 3). Think of it a bit like "text speak" in English. You know what "hw abt nxt wdnsday?" means because your brain inserts the right vowels automatically. 

Some words are written with the same letters but have different nikud and are pronounced differently - without the dots, the pronunciation can often be determined by context. In this case we will help you by adding nikud where necessary.

***Please Note!*** when writing your Hebrew answers, don't use the vowels - just write words without vowels.

 Here is a table of the most common ones (where we will use  as an example carrier letter):

Vowel|IPA|English example
---|---|---
|silent/e| mm (long sound), y**e**t
  | a | b**a**nk
  | e | b**e**d
 | i | b**ee**p
  | o | b**o**g
  | u | z**oo**

In addition, the letter "" can carry two kinds of vowels:

Vowel|IPA|English example
---|---|---
|o|b**o**g
|u|z**oo**

-----------
"Dagesh"
-----------
As well as denoting vowels, dots can be used to explicitly distinguish between letters that have two different pronunciations:

|Letter|Pronunciation with dot|Pronunciation without dot|
|:---:|:---:|:---:|
|b|v|
|k|kh|
|p|f|

In technical terms the letters with the dot are plosives, and are usually used at the start of a syllable, while the letters without the dot are fricatives and are usually used at the end of a syllable. In writing without nikud, a letter without a dot could have either pronunciation, but its position in the syllable will help you guess the right pronunciation. For example:

klev   (start of syllable)  
mlekh   (end of syllable)

The letter , with a dot at the top right represents "sh", while , with the dot at the top left, represents "s".

*These sounds are pronounced only when the letter is at the beginning of the word or at the beginning of a syllable. Otherwise, the other sound will be the one that is pronounced.

**A common example for the use of "" as a silent letter is the word:  (/lo/) - which means "no".

-----------
***Ktiv mal: "Full Spelling"***
-----------

In modern Hebrew we usually don't use vowel dots (nikud), which is why we will learn to read without them. Ktiv mal ("full spelling") is a way of writing which helps us to do so.

In *ktiv male* we use letters to replace some of the nikud, so in fact, it's not strictly true that Hebrew is written without vowels. 

Letter| IPA | English example | Hebrew example
---|---|---|---
 |o| l**o**g | **** (****rez - rice)
 |u| z**oo** | **** (h**u** - he is)
 |e| b**e**d | **** (h****seg - accomplishment)
 |i| b**ee**p | **** (h**ee** - she is)
,,| a|r**a**g| **** (r**a** - bad)
,,| e|b**e**d|**** (kor**** - reads)


There are also a few guidelines you can use to help you:

1.When a word ends with the letter "", the end is always pronounced as "akh" (*"aX"*).

>
- **** (r**akh** - wind)
- ****(m**akh** - brain)
- **** (s**akh** - bush/conversation)
- **** (r'**akh** - smell)
- **** (pr**akh** - flower)
- **** (tap**akh** - apple)

2.When a word ends with the letter "", the end is always pronounced as "a" (*"a"*, *"a"*)

>
- **** (shom**a** - hears)
- **** (kv*a** - a hat)
- **** (tsb**a** - a finger)
- **** (kark**** - ground)

3.In some words, we use the diphthong "" for "ai", "ey" and "ya":

>
-  (hey - hey)
-  (bai - bye)
-  (yain - wine)

4.When we want to pronounce the sound "v" we double the letter  (vav) - since when we are not using nikud, the letter  is used to indicate when there is a vowel, "o" or "u":

>
-  (avr - air)
-  (mevatr - gives up)
-  (mutr - allowed)

**Note:** when the letter  appears in the beginning of the word there is no need to double it - it will nearly always be "v". Eg.  vard (pink)

5.When a word ends with the combination "", it will mostly be pronounced as "av".

>
- **** (akhsh**v**)
- **** (al**v**)

skills.tipsAndNotes:
NEW USERS AND PEOPLE NEW TO HEBREW: See [here](https://duolinguists.wordpress.com/typing-in-hebrew-learning-alef-bet-for-beginners/) for quick instructions on **typing** and **learning to read** Hebrew.

Welcome
------------

The word "welcome" has 4 versions:

* ** ** (barkh hab) - for singular masculine.

* ** ** (brukh haba') - for singular feminine.

* ** ** (brukhm haba'm) - for plural masculine/mixed (and when no one in particular is being addressed, for example on a place sign).

* ** ** (brukht haba't) - for plural feminine.

----------
Names
----------

In this lesson we introduce two common Israeli names:

 (Yossi) - Male name (shortened from the equivalent of "Joseph", Yosef - )

 (Tal) - Unisex name (meaning "dew")

-----------
How are you?
-----------

As in English, there are various ways to ask someone how they are, or what's going on. Here we introduce the following:

?   
Literally: "What's happening?" Similar to "What's up?", "How are you doing?"

?   
Literally: "What is heard?" Used in the same way as  .

?   
(when addressing a male:   (ma shlomkh), when addressing a female:   (ma shlomkh))  
Literally this means "what is your peace/well-being/welfare?". This is the standard, formal way of asking "how are you?".

--------------
Congratulations and good luck!
--------------

The Hebrew phrase for "congratulations" is " " (maz**a**l tov) - not "**ma**zel tov" like in Yiddish!
Literally it means "good luck" but it isn't used to wish someone good luck, it simply means that they have already had some good luck (mazal = luck; tov = good).

The Hebrew phrase for "good luck" is  (be'hatzlakha), literally "in/with success".

skills.name: Basics
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**To Be**
-----------
In Hebrew the verb "to be" doesn't exist in the present tense - meaning that there is no "am" , "is" or "are" in Hebrew (Except for a few specific cases which will be taught later). So what do we do? We simply omit them. Instead of saying "I am", you just say "I".

In Hebrew all pronouns except "I" and "We" have a masculine and a feminine form. When using verbs or adjectives with "I" or "We", choosing the correct form is a matter of the speaker's gender. If the speaker is male, he will use the masculine form, while a female speaker will use the feminine form. (the first person pronoun(I/We) will remain the same, since it is neutral).
For example : 

>    - I like (sg. fem.) water. - the speaker is a female

>    - I like (sg. masc.) water. - the speaker is a male

When it comes to the pronoun "we", one should use the plural feminine form only when the group is not mixed - in that case, we use the plural masculine form.

We have already learnt the singular pronouns in the Letters skills, so in this lesson we will learn the plural pronouns.

Let's have a look at the Hebrew pronouns:

English| Hebrew | Pronunciation
---|---|---
I am |  | Ani
You are (singular masculine) |  | Ata
You are (singular feminine) |  | At
He is |  | Hu
She is |  | Hee
We are |  | Anakhnu
You are (plural masculine) |  | Atem
You are (plural feminine) |  | Aten
They are (masculine) |  | Hem
They are (feminine) |  | Hen

When using "you" (plural) or "they" for a mixed group, the masculine plural is used.

----------------
**Grammatical Genders**
----------------
We have two grammatical genders (masculine and feminine), and each of them has both singular and plural forms.

There is no exact way to know what the gender of each noun is, but you can use this guideline to help you - most of the feminine nouns end with ""(a) or ""(t) (keep in mind that there are some masculine nouns with these endings, but not many).

Moreover, if the noun is related to a person, you can almost always determine its grammatical gender through the person's gender. 

For example, the grammatical gender of the noun "mom" is feminine.

--------------------------------------
Unlike in English, Hebrew uses the third-person pronouns "he" and "she" when referring to both animate and inanimate nouns (while English refers to humans alone with those words). There is no "it".

When using a third-person pronoun to replace a noun, the pronoun used is the pronoun of the corresponding grammatical gender. Let's take a look at an example:

The grammatical gender of the noun "apple" is *masculine*. 

We will take the sentence:

  - ha'tapakh ta'm (the apple is tasty)

If we want to refer to the same apple in another sentence, we will say:

  - hu taim (*lit:* he is tasty)

In English, one says "*it* is tasty".  
The same goes for *all* nouns.

----------------
**Verb Conjugation**
----------------
In Hebrew, present tense verbs conjugate according to gender and number. 

For example, the pronoun "he", will a receive a singular masculine verb, and the pronoun "they (f)" will a receive a plural feminine verb.

Here is the basic verb conjugation:

-|Masculine|Feminine
---|---|---
Singular| (ochel)|**** (ochel**et** )
Plural|**** (ochl**im**)|**** ( ochl**ot**)

For the few verbs whose masculine singular form contains only 2 letters, the verb conjugation is as follows:

-|Masculine|Feminine
---|---|---
Singular| (ba)|**** ( ba**'ah**)
Plural|**** (ba**im**)|**** (ba**ot**)

-----------
Magic !
-----------

When verbs end with , they conjugate a bit differently than normal verbs:

1.  The singular form (masculine/feminine) is determined by the vowels of the letter before "".

2. In the plural form, the "" is omitted.

For example:

-|Masculine|Feminine
---|---|---
Singular| **** (ro'**e**h) | **** (ro'**a**h)
Plural| **** (ro'**im**) |  **** (ro'**ot**)

As you can see in the singular masculine form, the letter before "" has a "e" vowel (ro'eh), and in the singular feminine form it has an "a" vowel (ro'ah).

skills.name: There is/To Have
skills.tipsAndNotes:
To Have
-----------
In Hebrew, there is no verb "to have". Instead, in the present tense, we use the word ""(yesh) - "there is" and a conjugation of the preposition "" (le = "to").

For example, "" (lanu) = to us. Using it together with "" (yesh = there is) will form: 

  (yesh lanu) = we have (literally, "there is to us").

Here is a table of indirect pronouns with :

English | Hebrew | Pronunciation
---|---|---
I have |   | yesh li
You have (s.m) |   | yesh lech
You have (s.f.) |   | yesh lach
He has |   | yesh lo
She has |   | yesh la
We have |   | yesh lnu
You have (p.m.) |   | yesh lakhm
You have (p.f.) |   | yesh lakhn
They have (m.) |   | yesh lahm
They have (f.) |   | yesh lahn

When using "you (plural) have" or "they have" for a mixed group, use the masculine plural.

If we want to say that one does not have something, we use the word "" ("ein", but mostly pronounced colloquially as "en") instead of "".

For example:

* ****   - I have an apple

* ****   - I don't have an apple  (literally "there is not to me apple")

Similarly, we add "" (le = "to") to any other noun that is the possessor of something:

For example: 

 +  =  = **le**yled - to a boy
  - a boy has

If we are adding  to an object that has  (the) already attached at the beginning, we remove  and add . The pronunciation will be "la", not "le":

 +  =  = **la**yled - to *the* boy

How do we know whether  means "to a boy" or "to the boy"? Context! (Or if there is nikud:  versus ).

----------
Word Order
-----------

Usually the word order for sentences referring to possession is as follows (reading right to left):

thing possessed + possessor +  +  

For example:  
    
  

An alternative order places the possessor at the start of the sentence, as follows:  
    
This has the effect of placing more emphasis on the possessor than on the object possessed: "the **boy** (it's the boy, and not the girl, or the frog) has an apple". 
 
This example may help you to understand the difference:  
  ,     
***the boy*** has an apple, but ***I*** don't.

skills.name: Introduction to adjectives
skills.tipsAndNotes:
We use adjectives to describe objects.

Sentence Structure
-----------------

In Hebrew, the adjective is placed **after** the noun. For example (the adjective is in bold):

**little** dog =  **** (kelev **katan**)

-----------------
Conjugation of Adjectives
-----------------

Adjectives in Hebrew decline according to the grammatical gender and number **of the noun they are referring to**.

Adjective conjugation is almost identical to present tense conjugation. (In fact, you will come to see that the distinction between adjective, verb and noun is very blurred at times in Hebrew!)

- Normal adjective conjugation:

-|Masculine|Feminine
---|---|---
Singular|  (tov) | **** (tov**a**)
Plural| **** (tov**im**) | **** (tov**ot**)

- Adjectives that end with the letter "":

-|Masculine|Feminine
---|---|---
Singular| **** (yaf**e**) | **** (yaf**a**)
Plural| **** (yaf**im**) | **** (yaf**ot**)

----------
Summary of Simple Phrase Structures
----------

The book is good -    
The good book -    
A good book -  

How do we say "a book is good"? We use the personal pronouns kind of like a "to be" verb:

A book is good -    literally "(a) book he/it (is) good"

For a feminine noun, you need to use :

A bird is beautiful -   

These a fairly unusual, uncommon sentences in both Hebrew and English, but they serve as an example, and a reminder that   almost always means "(a) good book" and *not* "a book is good".

And of course, you need the plural for plural nouns:

Children/Boys are good -     
Girls are good -

skills.name: Food 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**The accusative**
--------------
When an action is being done to a noun, we call that noun "the direct object".

You will remember from Letters 1 that there is no indefinite article ("a"/"an") in Hebrew, and that in order to add a definite article ("the") to a noun we simply connect the letter  to the noun.

However, when that noun is the *direct object* of the sentence, we also need to add another word before it. This word has no English equivalent or translation, and all it does is it tells you that the noun which is about to follow is the direct object. For now you only need to use it with the definite article, . If you find words like "definite", "article" and "direct" confusing, don't worry! Duolingo is designed to help you understand when to use words like  through practice. 

Try not to confuse  *et*, with the identically-spelled  *at*. You can tell which pronunciation to use from the context. (See the example at the bottom of this page)

Examples using  *et*:

   - A boy eats an apple.

****   - **The** boy eats an apple.

  *** *** - A boy eats ***the*** apple.

****  *** *** - **The** boy eats ***the*** apple.

If the direct object is a name, then  is still required, but we don't add :  
     
The boy eats Yossi!

*et* vs *at*
-----------------
You can usually tell from the context whether  is to be pronounced as "et" or "at":

    - You (f) eat the apple. **at** okhlet **et** hatapakh

The first  is followed by a verb (a "doing word"), so it has to be *at*, "you". The second is followed by  + a noun which is **receiving** the action (it is **being eaten**), so it is *et*.

skills.name: Animals
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In Hebrew some animals have both masculine and feminine forms. If we use the masculine form, we are referring to a male animal, and if we use the feminine form, we are referring to a female animal.

In order to turn the masculine form of an animal into its feminine form, we often simply add "" to the end of the noun.

For example:

>A male cat -  (khatl)

>A female cat - **** (khatul****)

Some animals receive the letter "" instead of "".

For example:

>A male rabbit -  (arnv)

>A female rabbit - **** (arnv**et**) (The vowels also change a bit here. You will get used to seeing this pattern as you learn new words.)

Note that  (bird) is **feminine**, even though it ends in  in the plural. It is irregular:

  - Birds are singing. tsiporm shart

skills.name: Plurals
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In Hebrew we have 2 endings for nouns in the plural form:

****(im) - for masculine nouns.

****(ot) - for feminine nouns.

If the noun ends with the letter "" - we omit it before adding the plural ending.

For example:

>**** (par****) - cow

>**** (par**t**) - cows

If the word ends with a letter in its final form, we replace it with the original form, and then add the plural ending.

For example: 

> **** (itn) - newspaper.

> **** (itonm) - newspapers.

These are the basic rules. However, many masculine nouns have the feminine plural ending and vice versa. Unfortunately these irregular words are fairly unpredictable. For the most part you just have to learn them. 

For example,  (yain) - wine is a masculine noun, but the plural is  (yeint).  (dvor) -bee- is a feminine noun, but the plural is  (dvorm). Note that adjectives/verbs always agree with the gender of the noun regardless of its plural ending, so you would say *  - tasty wines* ; and not * *. 

***

We also have nouns that have both masculine and feminine forms. These nouns usually refer to humans and animals.

For example:

>**** (khatul**m**) - a male or mixed-gender group of cats (plural masculine).

>**** (khatul**t**) - female cats (plural feminine).

skills.name: Possessives 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
The word possessive word ""
--------------------------------

In Hebrew the basic possessive form is "" ("shel" meaning "of").  has additional forms for each person such as  (my),  (our), like the other prepositions in Hebrew.

To say "Yossi's apple", we literally say "The apple of Yossi":   . 

Now let's have a look at the inflections of the word "":

English | Hebrew
---|---
My | ****
Your (s.m.) | ****
Your (s.f.) | ****
His | ****
Her | ****
Our | ****
Your (p.m.) | ****
Your (p.f.) | ****
Their (m) | ****
Their (f) | ****

When talking **about** a noun being possessed - we add the word "" (the) to the noun. When we are talking **to** the noun, no "" is needed.

For example: 

*Talking **about** the horse:*

 ****   - My horse is eating. *Literally: "the horse of mine is eating" or "the horse that is to me is eating".*

*Talking **to** the horse:*

  ,  ! - Good morning, my horse! *Literally: "Good morning, horse of mine!".*

As you will have noticed, in Hebrew the possessive word always comes **after** the noun and not before it.

That means we say:  **** and not **** 

Do we always have to use the definite arcticle?
-----------------------------
There is another case when we dont need to use the word  - certain nouns dont require its use, even when we are talking about them. The most common example of such nouns is certain family members - for example, when talking about your:

 - father/dad

 - mother/mum/mom

 - brother

 - sister

For example,    - my mother is smart and not   .

The phrase " "
------------------
In Hebrew, like in English, you can use the word "belong" to indicate ownership. In Hebrew we use the word "":

-|Masculine|Feminine
---|---|---
Singular| (shaykh)| (shaykhet)
Plural| (shayakhm)| (shayacht)

Like in English, this words requires the preposition "to" ("-" in Hebrew) which we learned in the "There is" skill.

For example:
>
  ****= It belongs to me
>
  ****= the (female) cat belongs **to the** boy

Technically,  is (or was originally) an adjective, so it does not have an infinitive, or past and future tenses. The solution for this is to use the verb "to be" with . "To belong to" is -  .

skills.name: Adjectives 1 - Basics
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**Copula ()**
------------
When we want to define a **general** feature of an object (i.e. lemons are sour), we use the **copula** ().
The main purpose of the copula is to link the *subject* of a sentence with a *predicate*.

In simple terms, the copula is like the English verb "to be".

The copula in Hebrew uses the third person pronouns to describe objects (i.e.  
he/it   
she/it   
they (m)   
they (f) ).

For example:

Fish **are** tasty =  ****  (literally -  fish **they (are)** tasty).

This allows you to differentiate between:  
  - tasty fish  
and  
   - fish are tasty.



**Definite articles with adjectives**
------------
When adding definite articles to nouns with adjectives, **both** the noun and the adjective receive a definite article.

For example:

The big dog = **** **** (**ha**klev **ha**gadl).

This rule is also applicable when we use more than one adjective for the same noun.

The big beautiful dog = **** **** **** (**ha**klev **ha**gadl **ve'ha**yaf).  
Note that we say "big *and* beautiful".   is not as natural as "big beautiful" as in English.

So now you can differentiate between: 

*   = The dog is big (ha'kelev gadol)

*  **** = The big dog (ha'kelev **ha**'gadol)

**Possessives with adjectives**
-----------------
When you have a noun, an (attributive) adjective and a possessive, the possessive comes after both the noun and the adjective:

    
My new dog

*not*

skills.name: Direct Object
skills.tipsAndNotes:
We have already met the direct object connector: ""(et).

It is considered a preposition and we use it to mark a direct object (the receiver of an action). It appears when there is a definite article attached to the noun (i.e. "the" - "").

In some cases the word "" is not necessary to express a specific direct object, for example, nouns related to family members (mom, dad, sister, brother etc.), and people's names. That's because family members are usually specified (people usually have one mother and one father).

For example:
 
 "  ****  " - I love my mom.
"  **** " - I love Tal.

----------------------
The suffixes of the word ""
----------------------

The word "" has suffixes to indicate person and number, like every other preposition. Note that the plural "you" bucks the trend and starts with "et", not "ot":

English | Hebrew
---|---
Me | **** (ot**i**)
You (singular masculine) | **** (ot**kha**)
You (singular feminine) |**** (ot**akh**)
Him | **** (ot**o**)
Her | **** (ot**a**)
Us | **** (ot**anu**)
You (plural masculine) | **** (et**khem**)
You (plural feminine) | **** (et**khen**)
Them (masculine) | **** (ot**am**)
Them (feminine) | **** (ot**an**)

You might hear some native Israeli speakers using / (otkhem/otkhen) for the 2nd person plural, "you". This follows the pattern of "ot" used by the other persons of the word, but it is technically incorrect.

skills.name: Clothing
skills.tipsAndNotes:
We have some special verbs related to clothing:

  = to wear clothes

  = to wear shoes/boots/sandals

 = to wear a hat

 = to wear jewellery

  = to wear socks

 = to wear glasses

----------------------
Sounds of a non-Hebrew origin
----------------------
Some words in Hebrew originate from other languages which use sounds that aren't present in the conventional Hebrew alphabet. We put an apostrophe " **'** " after some letters to express these sounds:

Hebrew | IPA |English example
---|---|---
'  |  d  | **j**eans 
'|    | bei**ge** 
'|  t  | **ch**air

Some less common sounds (which are generally only used for foreign names) are:

Hebrew | IPA |English example
---|---|---
'| | **th**en
| w | **w**ag
'||**th**ing

**Note:** this is just an apostrophe, try not to confuse it with the letter "  " (yod). The apostrophe sits above the top line of most letters, whereas the letter  is in line with them:

In the word ' "jeans", you can see this fairly clearly.

If the font supports the traditional shape of the *geresh*, it is in line with the top of the letters, but it is slanted, unlike the letter :

skills.name: Verbs: Present - Pa'al
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Binyanim
---------
Binyanim ("constructions") are a formulaic way of creating lots of different verbs in Hebrew in a predictable way. There are seven binyanim and each binyan is a set of patterns for each tense. Most verbs in Hebrew have a 3 letter root (some have 4) from which you can derive every kind of word and it is this root which is inserted into a binyan - a set of patterns that can be a mixture of prefix letters, suffix letters and vowels. This is not such an alien concept for speakers of English after all. For example, the sounds "s" and "ng" produce words with several different but related meanings when different vowels are inserted in between: "sing", "sang", "sung", "song". 

Some roots are expressed in several of the binyanim, while others only exist in one binyan (don't be intimated by the system of binyanim - you don't have to learn several conjugations for each root word). To put it basically, three of the binyanim are for active verbs ("doers" of the action) and three are for passive verbs (receivers of the action), while the final one is usually for reflexive actions (an action done to oneself). Other differences between the binyanim can be to do with whether the verb is transitive or intransitive ("the boy **grows**" and "the boy **grows** *plants*" use different binyanim), or causative ("write" versus "dictate", "learn" versus "teach"), but we will come to all this in due course.


The construction  (pa'al)
---------
This skill will focus on verbs in the binyan called  (pa'al) in the present tense, which is the most basic and most commonly used binyan, and includes most of the basic verbs. This binyan is **active and transitive**.

The most common pattern of the construction pa'al in the present tense is:  
**(XoXeX) XXX **  
(the "X" is replaced by the root letters):

|X|X|X|final verb
-|-|-|-
|||  (**o**ch**e**l)
|||  (k**o**t**e**v)
|||  (**o**m**e**r)

Using the root "  " which is for words connected to eating we have the following conjugation:

-|Masculine|Feminine
---|---|---
Singular| (ochel)|**** (ochel**et** )
Plural|**** (ochl**im**)|**** (ochl**ot**)

**Two cases to watch out for**:

* Verbs that end with the letter "" in the singular form.
For these verbs the verb conjugation in the singular form is different only in the vowels (with no nikud they look the same).
In the plural forms, the "" is omitted.
For example:

-|Masculine|Feminine
---|---|---
Singular|**** (shot**e**) | ****(shot**a**)
Plural|**** (shot**im**)|**** (shot**ot**)

* Verbs that contain only 2 letters in the basic form.
For these verbs the verb conjugation is as follows:

-|Masculine|Feminine
---|---|---
Singular| (ba)|**** (ba**'a**)
Plural|**** (ba**im**)|**** (ba**ot**)

, 
---------

One more slightly strange one. A very small number of verbs which are considered related to this binyan are conjugated slightly differently:  

* , , ,  *gadel*, *gdela*, *gdelim*, *gdelot* ("grow", "growing")  

* , , ,  *yashen*, *yeshena*, *yeshenim*, *yeshenot* ("sleep", "sleeping")

These verbs are called  (pa'el) verbs, but they only differ from regular pa'al verbs in the present tense.

***

 To know - / 
---------
In Hebrew, there are two verbs that correspond to "to know" in English:

-  is used for knowing an item of knowledge.

-  more literally means "to be familiar with" and is used for people, places and living things. You'd also use it in a context when you would say in English "I have heard of it" -     i.e. "I am familiar with it".

- The **important** thing to note is that using  about a *person* means to "know" them *in the biblical sense* - so be careful not to use it about something alive unless that is what you actually mean.

***

To read/to call - 
---------
Note that the verb  has two meanings - "to read" (as in "to read a book") and "to call" (as in "to call your name" - not calling with a phone or any other communication device (this has another verb which will be taught later in the course)).

***

In / in the - 
---------
Finally, you may see the letter "" attached at the front of words. This preposition means "in" and is found in front of words just like "":

 (y'ar) - a forest

 (ha-y'ar) - the forest

 (be-y'ar) - in a forest

To say "in the", " + " (be + ha) is contracted to "" (ba):

 (ba-y'ar) - in the forest

Without niqqud, this looks the same as  - "in a". Context determines whether or not to include the "the". Some verbs require this particular preposition where it is unusual in English:

   - "He touches me"

---------
**Continuous (progressive)** 

And now for some good news! Hebrew doesn't have a separate continuous aspect (eg. he **is** runn**ing**), so both "he runs" and "he is running" translate to  .

skills.name: Colors
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Many colors in Hebrew fit the following pattern, in which the masculine singular includes the vowel "o", while the other conjugations include the vowel "u".

o -> u pattern:
---
Using  (purple) as an example:

|masculine singular|feminine singular|masculine/mixed plural|feminine plural|
|:-----|------|------:|  
|||||
|sagl|sgul|sgulm|sgult|

---------
The colors black ( shakhr) and gray ( afr) follow a slightly different pattern, in which the "o" sound **doesn't** change to an "u" sound in the plural and  feminine singular conjugations:

o -> o pattern:
---
Using  as an example:  

|masculine singular|feminine singular|masculine/mixed plural|feminine plural|
|:-----|-----|------:|  
|||||
|shakhr|shkhor|shkhorm|shkhort|

skills.name: Prepositions 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Prepositions in Hebrew fall into two main categories: those whose personal pronoun forms are based on a singular stem and those that are based on a plural stem. Here we will introduce some prepositions from the former group:

|Person| Pronunciation| Suffix |
|:--------:|:---------:|:--------:|
|me| -i | - |
|you (sg. m)| -kha | -|
|you (sg. f)|-ekh/-akh| -|
|him| -o| -|
|her|-a| -|
|us|-enu/-anu | -|
|you (pl. m)|-khem|-|
|you (pl. f)|-khen|-|
|them (m)|-am| -|
|them (f)|-an|-|

So taking the word , meaning "for" (in the sense of "intended *for* somebody/something"), we can make the following:

for me -   (bishvil**i**)

for us -  (bishvil**enu**) 

for them (f) -   (bishvil**an**) 

etc.

**Notice** that some prepositions have different stand-alone forms. A prime example is  (with) which turns into - when suffixes are added:

with the dog -    
with him - 

*The reason for this is that originally we had  (along with , ,  etc. which have since become rare) and  (et), functioning as "with", not as the direct object marker. Nowadays,  is only ever used as the direct object marker.*

---------------------------------------

Here is a table of the prepositions we teach during this unit:

English meaning| Stand-alone form| Base of suffixed form
-|-|-
in, at (*attached*) | - | -
from| -/ | --/-/
with |  | -
for |  | -
next to, beside|  | -
inside, within|| -
against|| -

-----------------------------------------

Using  properly
--------------
The preposition  (inside) cannot be used alone (without an object) in any context.
For example, you can't say   (I am inside) - because you have to add an object following the preposition . (e.g.    - I am inside the restaurant).

In order to translate the adverb "inside", you need to use a different word, which will be introduced properly in Prepositions 2. This word,  *bifnm* does not require (and actually cannot have) a preposition attached to it. 

I am inside -    
I am inside the house -

skills.name: Numbers 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In Hebrew, numbers have both masculine and feminine forms:

 (shalosh - three, feminine)  
 (shlosha - three, masculine)

Notice that contrary to what you might expect, the form ending in  ("a") is the ***masculine*** form:

three girls -    
three boys/children -  

It is also important to note that the form used for neutral numbers which aren't describing any real objects (for example when one counts), is the ***feminine*** form: 

..., , ,   
three, four, five, six...

**Number One**
--------------

Most numbers in Hebrew come before the noun, as in English. The number "one" is an exception. "One" always comes after the noun:

One boy -    
One girl -  

**Number Two**
--------------

The number "two" is also a little bit special in Hebrew. The forms of the word used when they are not followed by a noun are:

 (feminine/neutral)  
 (masculine)

For example:

?     
.  
How many peppers do you want?  
Two.

Different forms are used when the number is followed by a noun:

Two peppers -   (shnei pilpelim)  
Two bananas -   (shtei bananot)

**Number Eight**
--------------

The number eight is written the same for both feminine and masculine forms. The only difference is the vowel system:

 (eight, feminine) - shmon**e**

 (eight, masculine) - shmon**a**

**The numbers 11-19**
--------------

Let's take the number "13" as an example:

In Hebrew the number "13" is:

* Feminine -   (shlosh esre)
* Masculine -   (shlosha asar)

As you can see in the masculine form, we take the maculine form of the number three () and we add "asar"  ( - which is a variation on the number ten - eser).

In the feminine form we do the same, but we add "esre" () instead.

More examples:

Eleven:

* Feminine -   (achat esre)
* Masculine -   (achad asar)

Fifteen:

* Feminine -   (khamesh esre)
* Masculine -   (khamisha asar)

**Note:** there might be slight changes in the pronunciation of some numbers.

For example:

- sh**a**losh (feminine form of three).

- shlosh esre (feminine form of thirteen).

**The numbers 20 and 0**
--------------

The numbers twenty ( - esrim) and zero ( - efes) are neutral, i.e. when adding them to a feminine or a masculine noun, they don't conjugate.

--------------------
**More than/Less than**
--------------------

The word "than" is represented by adding the preposition -, which more commonly translates as "from":

   ****  
Four is more **than** three.

skills.name: Questions
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Questions
----------

As mentioned earlier, the word  (ha'im) can be used optionally in questions when there are two possible answers (such as "yes"/"no", "him"/"her"):

Is it him or her? ?      
Do you like the cake? ?    

These sentences are of course perfectly fine without , which is slightly formal, but it can be used to stress the fact that you are asking a question rather than making a statement. 

The word  can **never** be used in open questions, that is, ones which use a question word such as "how", "where", "when", "who".


Which?
-------
The words for "which?" in Hebrew *should* agree with the noun being described:

Which dog? ?   
Which cow? ?   
Which boys? ? 

You will find that in Modern Hebrew people very often just use the singular masculine form, , instead of the plural , and to a lesser extent,  instead of the feminine  for feminine nouns. You should try to refrain from this habit, although we do often allow these technically incorrect answers due to the frequency of occurrence among native speakers.

------------------------------

The default gender and number in questions is third person masculine singular. If you know the gender or number you can change the verb accordingly:

Who is eating all the apples? ?      
(Addressing the question to two girls) Who is eating all the apples? ? ****

skills.name: Determiners
skills.tipsAndNotes:
This/That
-------
There isn't a clear distinction in Hebrew between "this" and "that": both are covered by  (masculine - ze) and  (feminine - zot).  (zo) is also a common equivalent for , and we accept it as an answer but we stick to  throughout the course. 

We have seen that to say "this is a dog" we put  first:

 

To say "this dog", we put  after the noun, as if it were a normal adjective, and it requires , like other adjectives:

this dog =    
this cow =  

-------
These/Those
-------
The same applies to "these" and "those": both are covered by a single word. In the plural, masculine and feminine words both use "" (ele). We also teach the word , which in Modern Hebrew has exactly the same meaning, although it is less common and slightly higher register than the former, .

these dogs =  /  
those cows =  /

-------
/ 
-------
When  is followed by a noun in the singular without , it means "each" or "every":

each/every day =    
each/every dog =   

When it is followed by a noun with , it means "all":

all day =    
all night  =     
all the cows =  

-------
"The same"
---------
To express the word "same" in Hebrew, we use the appropriate inflected form of :

-  - for singular masculine nouns.

-  - for singular feminine nouns.

-  - for plural masculine nouns.

-  - for plural feminine nouns.

along with whichever other preposition is needed in the circumstances:

- I see **the same** thing =     ** **  

- I answer **the same** girl =   ** **  

- He swims under **the same** fish(p) =    **  **

- I am helping **the same** women =   ** **

The use of  before the noun is optional. We can equally say:

     (Notice that "" is omitted because there is no definite article)

     
      
   

This structure is also equivalent to the English "that very", as in "On that very (same) day":  . 

-------
None, nobody etc.
----------
Standard Hebrew, like many other languages, makes use of double negatives ("he didn't do *nothing*", rather than "he didn't do anything"). Therefore we say:

* I don't see "no one" (anybody) =        
* I don't see "no thing" (anything) =     

   is the same as  (nothing). 

Both  and  literally mean "not a single". 

 can be used with any noun, as can , but  is more common in everyday language:

He doesn't want a shirt      
He doesn't want any shirt (not a single one of them)      

-------
Impersonal Plural
-----------

In this unit we also introduce what we call the "impersonal plural". At times you may come across plural forms of verbs in Hebrew that are not connected to a personal pronoun. For example, a "normal" sentence with a plural form of a verb would be: 

* They eat apples. - .  

But when you see a sentence like:

   

Does it mean "We eat", "They eat", or "You (all) eat"?

The answer is that it can be all of these and more! In fact, it is sometimes hard to translate this type of sentence into English without context. There are several options that can be considered:

* One eats apples. (Can sound a bit old-fashioned nowadays.)
* You eat apples. (You as in "anybody" - can be confused for *actual* "you")
* We/They eat apples. (You have to know who is being spoken about, to know whether the speaker is including or excluding him/herself from the group)
* Apples are eaten. (At times using the passive can be the most elegant solution, but is not always an option)

Polyglots should be able to find parallels with the ways in which many other languages create impersonal expressions:  
French: On mange les pommes.  
German: Man isst pfel.  
Spanish: Se comen manzanas/Uno come manzanas.
Dutch: Men eet appel.

At times it can also have a suggestive tone. For example, if someone says  , it can be equivalent to "one speaks Hebrew", but can also mean something like "you should be speaking Hebrew!".

skills.name: Occupations
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Occupations in Hebrew have both masculine and feminine forms.

In order to turn a masculine form into a feminine form we add "" or "" to the end of the word.

For example:

  - He is a student (masculine)

 **** - She is a student (feminine)

---

  - The man is a director (masculine)

 **** - The woman is a director (feminine)

skills.name: Conjunctions
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Conjunction words in Hebrew are very simple and similar to English.

**The conjunction word ""**
---------------
The conjunction ""(that) is attached to words exactly like "" , "" , "" and other prepositions that we've already learned.

For example:

>  ****   - I think **that** he is sleeping.

This conjunction word is always pronounced as "she".
In our example the transliteration is: 

Ani khoshev **she**hu yashen.

Another thing we should remember when we use conjunctions is that some of them require the conjunction "".

For example:

-  **** = While (literally - in time that)

>   ****  = I eat while (**that**) he is sleeping.

-  **** = When(ever) (literally - when that)

>   ****  = I go when(ever) (**that**) you go


When using question words as conjunctions,  is essential:

I go **where** you go   ** **   


**The conjunction word ""**
---------------
The conjunction word ""(because of) requires the definite article "". 

For example:

>   ** ** = I don't sleep **because of** the boy.

When this conjunction is related to a pronoun, we omit the "" and use the conjugation of this conjunction word. This conjunction word conjugates identically to 
the first prepositions we learned, following the singular pattern:

Hebrew|Pronunciation|English
---|---|---
****| Biglal**i**|Because of me
****| Biglal**cha**|Because of you(singular masculine)
****| Biglal**ech**|Because of you(singular feminine)
****| Biglal**o**|Because of him
****| Biglal**a**|Because of her
****| Biglal**enu**|Because of us
****| Biglal**chem**|Because of you(plural masculine)
****| Biglal**chen**|Because of you(plural feminine)
****| Biglal**am**|Because of them(masculine)
****| Biglal**an**|Because of them(feminine)

skills.name: Prepositions 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In this lesson we introduce the second group of prepositions, whose personal pronoun forms are based on a plural stem:

|Person| Pronunciation| Suffix |
|:--------:|:---------:|:--------:|
|me| -ay | - |
|you (m)| -ekha | -|
|you (f)|-ayikh| -|
|him| -av| -|
|her|-eha| -|
|us|-enu | -|
|you (mp)|-ekhem|-|
|you (fp)|-ekhen|-|
|them (m)|-ehem| -|
|them (f)|-ehen|-|

For example, with the word  (el), meaning "toward(s)", "to", we have the following:

|English| Pronunciation| Hebrew|
|:--------:|:---------:|:--------:|
|toward me| elay |  |
|toward you (m)| elekha |  |
|toward you (f)|elayikh| |
|toward him| elav| |
|toward her|eleha| |
|toward us|elenu | |
|toward you (mp)|elekhem||
|toward you (fp)|elekhen||
|toward them (m)|elehem| |
|toward them (f)|elehen||

****
-------------
Although Hebrew doesn't always make use of a word equivalent to "is" in English (eg.   the cat *is* small), when talking about locations of things, we often use the word  (literally "is found"). 

So "the shoes are outside" can be translated as "  ". ("the shoes are found/located outside")

skills.name: Possessives 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Possessive nouns
------------

Instead of using "" (see Possessives 1), every noun in Hebrew can also express a possessive connection by declining using the Hebrew genitive case. This form is usually used in formal speech and less likely to be used in normal daily language where we usually use the word "", although certain words (family, body parts) are commonly used in this form in daily usage.

For this example we will use the noun "" (a horse):

English Singular | Hebrew Singular | English Plural | Hebrew Plural
---|---|---|---
My horse | **** (sus**i**) | My horses | ****(sus**ai**)
Your (s.m.) horse | **** (sus**cha**) | Your(s.m.) horses | **** (sus**echa**)
Your (s.f.) horse | **** (sus**ech**) | Your(s.f.) horses | **** (sus**aich**)
His horse | **** (sus**o**) | His horses | **** (sus**av**)
Her horse | **** (sus**a**) | Her horses | **** (sus**e(h)a**)
Our horse | **** (sus**enu**) | Our horses | **** (sus**enu**) 
Your (p.m.) horse | **** (sus**chem**) | Your(p.m.) horses | **** (sus**echem**)
Your (p.f.) horse | **** (sus**chen**) | Your(p.f.) horses | **** (sus**echen**)
Their (m) horse | **** (sus**am**) | Their(masucline horses | **** (sus**ehem**) 
Their (f) horse | **** (sus**an**) | Their(feminine) horses | **** (sus**ehen**)

This table might seem a little confusing, but once you try it a few times you'll get used to it! Moreover, you can see that the ending of the singular nouns are the same as the conjugations of the word "", and in order to make a singular possessive noun into a plural possessive noun, we simply add the letter "" before the ending.

For example :
>  +  (Your (s.m.) horse).

>  + **** +  (Your (s.m.) horse**s**).

When words have possessive endings attached to them, they are always definite, so when in an object position, they must be preceded by :

  ****   
I (can) see your horse.

skills.name: Verbs: Present - Pi'el
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**The 2nd construction:  (pi'el)**
---------
In the previous verbs skill, Present 1, we learned the basics of using binyanim and their basic rules. We are not going to repeat them here, so it might be a good idea to re-read the "Present 1" notes.

In Present 1 we learned verbs in the binyan "pa'al" in the present tense. This time we are going to learn about verbs in the binyan  "piel", the second most common binyan in Hebrew. Like the pa'al binyan, the piel binyan serves mostly for active verbs (as opposed to passive verbs). Piel verbs are also very often (but not always) transitive verbs, meaning that they require an object. For example, in the sentence "He changes *it*", the verb "change" is a piel verb in Hebrew, whereas in the sentence "He changes" (without an object), the verb "change" is translated using a different binyan, which we will cover later on. 

Piel verbs are conjugated using the following pattern, where X substitutes the root letters:

Note that all present tense verbs in binyan pi'el begin with "me".

|Person & Gender| Pronunciation| 
|:--------:|:---------:|
|Singular, Male| meXaXeX |
|Singular, Female| meXaXeXet|
|Plural/Mixed, Male|meXaXXim|
|Plural, Female| meXaXXot| 

So for example, the verb "to pay" conjugates like so:

|Pronunciation| Hebrew| 
|:--------:|:---------:|
|meshalm| |
|meshalmet| |
|meshalmm||
|meshalmt| | 

And when the verb ends in , we have the following conjugation:

|Person & Gender| Pronunciation| 
|:--------:|:---------:|
|Singular, Male| meXaXe |
|Singular, Female| meXaXa|
|Plural/Mixed, Male|meXaXim|
|Plural, Female| meXaXot| 

As in the verb "to change" (transitive):

|Pronunciation| Hebrew| 
|:--------:|:---------:|
|meshan| |
|meshan| |
|meshanm||
|meshant| |

------------------------------------

****

 (mevakr) can mean both "visit" and "criticize". Aside from context, the two meanings can be differentiated by their respective prepositions.  meaning "criticize" or "critique" is followed by  (et), while  as "visit" is followed by - when visiting places and followed by  when visiting people.

* She visits the restaurant -   ****  
* She visits Tal -   **** 
* She critiques the restaurant -   ** **

skills.name: Dates and Time
skills.tipsAndNotes:
The names of the days
----------------

The Hebrew week ends on Shabbat (Saturday), so naturally the first day of the week is Sunday (not Monday!). On the one hand, the names of the days in Hebrew are slightly easier to remember than in English, since literally we just say "first day", "second day", "fifth day" (and so on...), but if you are used to considering Monday as the first day of the week, you may have to get used to shifting each day along by one. For example, Friday isn't "fifth day", but "sixth day":  .

Saturday is an exception: we don't say  , but   or simply . Shabbat is the Jewish Sabbath (resting day) and this is in fact where the word Sabbath comes from. It's related to the word  "shev" meaning "sit", since it is the day for sitting and refraining from work. In Judaism, the day begins at sundown of the previous evening, so you might also come across  in reference to Friday night.

The dual form
----------------

In Semitic languages, originally there were three separate number distinctions: singular, plural, and dual. In Hebrew, the dual became uncommon even very early on, but it is retained in a number of words, often in body parts of which there are two (feet, knees, eyes etc.), and measurements of time:

Singular|Dual|Plural
---|---|---
 (sha'ah - a hour) | **** (sha'a**tayim** - two hours) |  (shaot - hours)
 (yom - a day) | **** (yom**ayim** - two days) |  (yamim - days)
 (shavu'ah - a week) | **** (shvu'**ayim** - two weeks) |  (shavu'ot - weeks)
 (khodesh - a month) | **** (khodsh**ayim** - two months) |  (khodashim - months)
 (shana - a year) | **** (shna**tayim** - two years) |  (shanim-years)

As you can see, the dual ending is "-ayim" for both masculine and feminine nouns, but feminine nouns which end with  have this letter replaced with  before the dual ending is added.

Note that it is unnatural to say, for example,  . You should always use the dual form, if one exists.

This + Time
----------------

When talking about time frames in Hebrew, you will come across an interesting phenomenon: the letter "" is attached to the time phrase, but doesn't function as a definite article.
Let's look at an example:

>   **** = he is leaving **this** week.

This can be used with many other time phrases:

* **** = this year (**ha**'shana).

* **** = this month (**ha**khodesh).

* **** = tonight (**ha**laila). **Side Note**:  is a masculine word.

* **** = this time (**ha**pa'am).

However, it can also be used as a definite article.
For example:

> ****  = **the** month passes

The meaning is determined by the context, but in some cases the sentence can mean either.

Hebrew months
--------------------

In the day-to-day life of the average Israeli, the calendar used is the same as in much of the world, so the names of the months are very similar to in English (yanuar, februar, september etc.). However, there is also a Hebrew lunisolar calendar, which is used in religious contexts. For example, the dates of religious festivals are determined according to their dates in the Hebrew calendar, so their date on the civil calendar changes from year to year. Since this isn't a course in Judaism, we don't teach the months of the Hebrew calendar here, although we do have a lesson at the end of the tree in which you will be able to learn about the most important Jewish holidays, which are celebrated by many Jewish Israelis, even secular ones.

vs

As you will notice in this lesson, the adjectives  (zakn) and  (yashn) have the same translation - old.
Be careful not to confuse the two, because both are extremely common and it will sound quite strange if you confuse them.

Many adverbs that end in "-ly" in English are paraphrased in Hebrew by using the word  ("way", "method"):

independent -   
independently -   (literally "in an independent way")

skills.name: Family
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**Cousins**

In Hebrew the word for a male cousin is literally son of uncle ( ), and the word for a female cousin is daughter of aunt ( ). Technically, son of aunt and daughter of uncle are possible, but in effect we like to group the genders together.

skills.name: Home Sweet Home
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**Toilet/Bathroom/Bath**

If you are out and about and need to relieve yourself, you ask for the  (sherutm - literally "services"). 

The actual toilet bowl is called the  (asla - not taught in the course but just FYI).

The bathtub is called the .

skills.name: Construct State 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In Hebrew grammar, the construct state (or adjacency) is known as **smichut** (). Smichut is a case in which two nouns (occasionally with different semantic meanings) are merged to create a new noun. A dash often separates the two nouns, indicating they are now in an adjacency relation.

The first noun in the construct is called the **nismach** () and the following noun **somech** (). The *gender* of the new composed noun is determined by the former. Meaning, if the *nismach* is a masculine noun, the new noun will also be masculine.
_______________________________________________

Most cases of smichut include the semantic addition of the word "of" between the two nouns. Let's take the following smichut, "a cup of coffee", as an example:

A cup -  (*kos*)  
Coffee -  (*cafe*)  

A cup (of) coffee -   (*kos cafe*)  

We can see that the word "of" () was omitted thanks to the efficiency of the construct state.
_______________________________________________

If the *nismach* is a **feminine** noun that ends with a "", the "" is replaced with a "":

A cake -  (*uga*)  
Chocolate -  (*shokolad*)  

A chocolate cake -   (*ugat shokolad* - literally "cake of chocolate")  
_______________________________________________

Also, **plural** constructs are created by pluralizing the *nismach*, but not the *somech*. If we use the same example as before:

Cups -  (*kosot*)  
Coffee -  (*cafe*)  

Cups of coffee -   (*kosot cafe*)  

A **masculine** plural *nismach* will change its form - a "" will be added to it:

An editor  -  (*orech*)  
Law -  (*din*)  

A Lawyer -   (*orech din*)  
Lawyers (m) -   (*orchey din*)  
_______________________________________________

In order to create a **definite smichut**, the definite prefix "" will precede the *somech*:

The cups of coffee -   (*kosot HA'cafe*)  
_______________________________________________

The most used (irregular) *nismach* is the word  ("house"). However, when  is a part of a smikhut, its nikkud is changed and the *nismach* becomes . Again, let's illustrate this through an example:

A house -  (*bayit*)  
A book -  (*sefer*)  

A school -   (*beyt sefer*)  

A house -  (*bayit*)  
Sick (people) -  (*cholim*)  

A hospital -   (*beyt cholim*)  
_______________________________________________

The construct state is not complicated, but requires some practice and memorizing. We chose to include the most common forms.

Good luck!

skills.name: Infinitives 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Infinitives in Hebrew work in much the same way as in English. The infinitive form of the verb starts with - (to). 

We have seen the binyanim pa'al and pi'el so far. This is how both conjugate in the infinitive:

**Pa'al**  

liXXoX  
eg. likhtv - 

**Pi'el**

leXaXeX  
eg. leshalm - 

Verbs which end in  in the singular present, end in  in the infinitive:

* to swim - liskht -   
* to change - leshant - 

Certain verbs are irregular in the infinitive. For example, "to take" is **** (lakkhat), and "to give" is **** (latt).

**How + infinitive**

You might come across a sentence where the question word "how" is used with an infinitive.
It might be translated as "How to ..." (e.g. how to do it?), but in some cases the translation could be a bit unnatural.

This kind of sentence could also be translated as "How does one..." / "How shall/do I/we..."

For example (when using the infinitive "" - to write): 

>    ? = How does one write this? / How do I write this etc.

skills.name: Verbs: Present - Hiph'il
skills.tipsAndNotes:
The construction:  (hiph'il)
---------------

Our third binyan is hiph'il (). This is the last of the active binyanim (after this we have the three passive binyanim and the reflexive binyan left). Like pi'el, verbs in this binyan are often transitive, meaning they act on an object (but not always). The hiph'il binyan is also often responsible for causative verbs. For example:

We have already seen the verb :

The dog returns (comes/goes back) -  

The verb  in hiph'il, means "to cause to return". In English the word "return" describes this meaning as well:

The dog returns (brings back) the newspaper -    

Another example:

I remember this -    

That reminds me -   

You can think of  as "causes to remember", and we have a word for this in English: "reminds".

--------------------------------------------

So let's have a look at the present tense conjugation of hiph'il verbs:

Note that all present verbs in binyan hif'il begin with "ma".

|Person & Gender| Pronunciation| 
|:--------:|:---------:|
|Singular, Male| maXXiX |
|Singular, Female| maXXiXa|
|Plural/Mixed, Male|maXXiXim|
|Plural, Female| maXXiXot| 

So for example, the verb "to agree" conjugates like so:

|Pronunciation| Hebrew| 
|:--------:|:---------:|
|maskm| |
|maskim| |
|maskimm||
|maskimt| | 

Notice that verbs in the construction hifl'il receive the ending "" (a) instead of ""(et) in the singular feminine form.

As usual, verbs ending with "" follow this pattern.

|Pronunciation| Hebrew| 
|:--------:|:---------:|
|mar'| |
|mar'| |
|mar'm||
|mar't| | 

And some verbs, which only have two root consonants, follow the pattern of "to understand":

|Pronunciation| Hebrew| 
|:--------:|:---------:|
|mevn| |
|mevin| |
|mevinm||
|mevint| | 

Notice the use of the "tzere" and "shva" vowels in this last pattern, which represent the "e" sound, in contrast to the other patterns which use "a" after the initial .

--------------------------------------------------------

In this lesson there are two verbs which translate as "listen":  and . The two words are fairly synonymous, although  is more common, while  is a little more formal. You would say    "I listen to music". However, you will often hear  on the radio:    "Hello listeners".

skills.name: People
skills.tipsAndNotes:
vs 
----------

In Hebrew a  can be both a friend and a boyfriend, depending on the context. The same goes for : friend and girlfriend. To avoid confusion, you may use the word /, which serves as "platonic friend".
Usually, when one gender calls the other gender " / " this means they are in a relationship.
For example, a boy will call his male friend "" but his female friend - . If he calls a girl "", it usually means she's his girlfriend - and vice versa. **Try to use the word / carefully in order to prevent embarrassment**


------------
In this lesson you will learn the word . This word can be both **adult** and **old** depending on the context. If it is functioning as a noun, it will necessarily be translated as "adult".

The "old" translation only applies to animate objects (like "" does) - for example -  old people, old man, old dog.
We usually use this version when we want to say that a person is not too old (because calling someone  can sometimes sound insulting).
So try not to call old people "" directly - using "" is much more proper.

skills.name: Numbers 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Definite Numbers
----------
When you want to say "the three cows" or "the seven boys", the phrase works like a construct. That is, the number goes into its construct form (shalosh -> shlosh, shlosha -> shloshet) and  is added to the noun:

three cows shalsh part    
the three cows (shlosh hapart)  

seven boys (shiv' yeladm)    
the seven boys (shiv't hayeladm)  

Use of the singular with some larger numbers
----------

Technically, all numbers from 11 upwards should take a singular noun in Hebrew, although in effect, with most words this sounds highly unnatural to native Hebrew speakers. Nevertheless, this rule *does* apply to some specific words, so it is possible to say both:

   
 

and in fact the second version, with  in singular is preferable.

This applies mostly to units of measurement, such as  (meter), currency (dollar, shekel), units of time (, ), "percent", and the word  (person/people).

----------
Genders of numbers above 19
----------
All round numbers above 19 (20, 30, 60 etc.) are neutral. Therefore, the gender of non-round numbers above 19 is only determined by the units digit. 

For example:

* 
  - forty five (feminine) - lit. forty (neutral) and five (feminine).

*   - forty five (masculine) - lit. forty (neutral) and five (masculine).

skills.name: Modals
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Several words in Hebrew that express modality (that is, likelihood, ability, permission, obligation, etc.) do not require a subject. For example:

    

It is recommended not to do that.

(And not **     )

skills.name: Education
skills.tipsAndNotes:
A student at school or in general is / (talmid/a).

A university/college student is / (student/it).

skills.name: Travel
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**Gender of Countries**

If in doubt, remember that most countries are feminine in gender, since  (country) and  (land) are feminine words. 

**Abbreviations**

In this skill we come across ". Abbreviations are very popular in Hebrew, and this is an abbreviation of  , literally meaning "outside of the land", but with the meaning "abroad". ( is another name for Israel, since Israel is sometimes known as   - the land of Israel. Note that in its normal form, it is pronounced rets, and in its construct form, it is rets.)

In Hebrew abbreviations, some representative letters are chosen, often depending on what will make the mostly easily pronounceable word, so the letters chosen are not necessarily just the first letter of each word. The gershayim (technically , but since on most keyboards it is much easier to type the double punctuation marks: ") are always placed just before the last letter.

Like in English, not all abbreviations are pronounced as words. 

NASA, for example, **is** pronounced "na-sa": ".  
But the USA, " is pronounced the same way as  : artst habrt.  
Unlike in English, it is uncommon to spell out abbreviations (like USA: yu-ess-aye).

skills.name: Verbs: Past Active 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Intoduction
-------------

So far we've learned 3 binyanim in the present tense (pa'al, pi'el and hif'il). 
The basic past form is always third-person singular masculine (i.e. "he - ") and to this form we add all suffixes. The names of the binyanim are derived from the third-person singular masculine form of the past tense, while using the root  -  - :

* Here are some example of third-person singular masculine past verb of the binyan  (pa'al):

 - sh**a**'**a**l (he asked)

 - k**a**t**a**v (he wrote)

* The same with  (pi'el):

 - d**i**b**e**r (he spoke)

 - s**i**ch**e**k (he played)

* And with  (hif'il):

 - h**i**rg**i**sh (he felt)

 - h**i**sb**i**r (he explained)

In the present tense, there are four conjugations, male/female and singular/plural. In the past tense, there is a different form for each pronoun. In the first person singular (I) there is only one form for both male and female, as is the case for the third person plural (they) and the first person plural (we). All the rest have a masculine and feminine form.

Let's take the verb  (amr - (he) said) as an example of the pa'al past tense:

|Pronoun | Suffix | Example|
|:-----:|:-----:|:-----:|
  | ~ (ti) | **** (amr**ti**)
 | ~ (ta) | **** (amr**ta**)
  | ~ (t) | **** (amr**t**)
  | - |  (amar)
 | ~ (a) | **** (amr**a**)
 | ~ (nu) | **** (amr**nu**)
  | ~ (tem) | **** (amr**tem**)
  | ~ (ten) | **** (amr**ten**)
  | ~ (u) | **** (amr****)
  | ~ (u) | **** (amr****) 

It is most natural to leave out the pronoun when using a verb in the past tense. Saying   is superfluous, since the ending of the verb tells you who is the subject of the verb. You can of course use the pronoun to add emphasis:

***I*** said that, not him -    ,  

**However**, the pronoun is not often left out for the *third person*, so you should always try to say:

 /   
/ 

----------------------------------------------------
Perfect aspect in Hebrew
----------------

You may be relieved to hear that in Hebrew there are no perfect aspects or tenses (in English, "have"/"had" done, for example). There is only one past conjugation, so  can mean "he did", "he has done" or "he had done". When translating from Hebrew into English, the context will inform you of the most natural way of writing the sentence.

-----------------------------------------------

To be
--------

As you probably remember from earlier lessons, the verb "to be" doesn't exist in the present tense.
However, it does exist in the past tense.

Let's have a look at the conjugations of the verb "to be" in the past tense ():

Pronoun | To be | English
-|-|-
 (an) |  (hayti) | I was
 (at) |  (hayta) | you (s.m.) were
 (at) |  (hayt) | you (s.f.) were
 (hu) |  (hay) | he was
 (hee) |  (hayt) | she was
 (ankhnu) |  (haynu) | we were
 (atm) |  (haytem) | you (pl.m.) were
 (atn) |  (hayten) | you (pl.f.) were
 (hem) |  (hay) | they (m.) were
 (hen) |  (hay) | they (f.) were

-----------------------------------------------

To have
--------

In the present tense, we use -  and -  to express "have" and "does not have". In the past tense (and future), we replace  and  with appropriate past forms of the verb "to be". The form of the verb must agree with the thing possessed or not possessed:

    
I had a dog. Literally "(he/it) was to me dog".

    
I had a car. Literally "(she) was to me car", because  is feminine.

     
I did not have dresses. Literally "not (they) were to me dresses".

-----------------------------------------------------------
Pi'el Pattern
-------------

|Example Verb|Pattern| Pronoun| 
|:--------:|:---------:|:-----------:|
| (dibrti)| XiXaXti ||
| (dibrta)|XiXaXta||
| (dibrt)| XiXaXt||
| (dibr)|XiXeX||
| (dibr)| XiXXa| |
| (dibrnu)| XiXaXnu||
| (dibrtem)|XiXaXtem||
| (dibrten)| XiXaXten| |
| (dibr)| XiXXu||
| (dibr)|XiXXu||


Hiph'il Pattern
-----------------

Note that all hiph'il verbs in the past tense start with "hi". 

|Example Verb|Pattern| Pronoun| 
|:--------:|:---------:|:-----------:|
| (hisbrti)| hiXXaXti ||
| (hisbrta)|hiXXaXta||
| (hisbrt)| hiXXaXt||
| (hisbr)|hiXXiX||
| (hisbra)| hiXXiXa| |
| (hisbrnu)| hiXXaXnu||
| (hisbrtem)|hiXXaXtem||
| (hisbrten)| hiXXaXten| |
| (hisbru)| hiXXiXu||
| (hisbru)|hiXXiXu||

skills.tipsAndNotes:
** vs **

    
and  
  

mean essentially the same thing: this is the best (one).  is the higher register option but still common in everyday speech.

skills.name: Verbs: Present Reflexive - Hitpa'el
skills.tipsAndNotes:
The 4th construction:  (hitpa'el)
---------------

Now we move onto the 4th binyan: hitpa'el (). This binyan is often used for verbs which express a **reflexive action** (something you do to yourself), or describe a certain **procedure**, often translated into English using verbs such as "get" or "become" + the adjective. For example:

I shave (myself) -    
He gets stronger -  

And as before, there are some words that do not seem to fit either description, but are still part of the binyan (in the past the connection may have been more obvious, and the meaning or usage may have changed since then). An example of this is the verb "to use". Note also that this verb requires the preposition :

I use the washing machine -   **** 

So let's look at the present conjugation for hitpa'el:

Note that **most** present tense verbs in binyan hitpa'el begin with "mit".

|Person & Gender| Pronunciation| 
|:--------:|:---------:|
|Singular, Male| mitXaXeX |
|Singular, Female| mitXaXeXet|
|Plural/Mixed, Male|mitXaXXim|
|Plural, Female| mitXaXXot| 

For instance, "get closer": 

|Pronunciation| Hebrew| 
|:--------:|:---------:|
|mitkarv| |
|mitkarvet| |
|mitkarvm||
|mitkarvt| | 

**Regular Irregularities**

The  that is added before the root consonants is highly susceptible to being affected by the first root consonant, that is, the one it immediately precedes. The first root consonant swaps places with the , and in some cases the  changes into  or . Luckily, the effect this has on the resultant conjugation is highly regular:

|First root letter| Result| Example|
|:--------:|:---------:|:---------:|
|| -||
|| -||
|| -||
|| -||

***Advanced***

*Hitpa'el verbs which have the dental consonants   or  as their first consonant are not very common, and this course does not include any, but for the sake of completeness:*

|First root letter| Result| Example|
|:--------:|:---------:|:---------:|
| | --/-/|  // (become blurred)|
| | --/-/|  // (play dumb)|
| | --/-/|  // (roll down/deteriorate)|

*The dental consonant can be "absorbed" by the  of hitpa'el, or can remain as is. In the case of absorption  can be added after the  to make it clear that it is a hitpa'el verb. The pronunciation depends on the speaker. A double-length pronunciation of the dental consonant is in free variation with a single-length pronunciation.*

skills.name: Adjectives 3
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**The adjective ""**

The adjective "" (garu'a - meaning "bad") is only used in terms of **quality**.

For example:

>    - this salad is bad.

(could be replaced with "poor", as in "poor quality")

Don't confuse it with the adjective "" which is used in this sort of situation (could be replaced by "evil"):

>     - he is not a bad person.

skills.name: Imperative 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Hebrew has a distinct conjugation for positive imperatives (commands). Increasingly, in modern Hebrew, the future tense is used for commands instead of the imperative. This is considered by some as an error, although using the future tense as an imperative can also sound less bossy and formal. It helps that the imperative and future are structurally related, as you will see in the first Future skill, coming up soon. You will also see that negative imperatives ("don't ... ") *require* the future. 

Nevertheless, it is important to know how to form the "true" imperative, and certain verbs, such  (come),  (go) and  (give), always use the "true" imperative in positive commands, not the future tense.

Imperatives: gender & number
==============
Hebrew imperatives have three forms (singular masculine, singular feminine and plural). A singular masculine imperative will be used when talking to one man.

Pa'al pattern
=========

|Pronunciation| Example Verb| Pattern|
|:-----:|:------:|:------:|
|ktov||XXoX|
|kitv|| XiXXi|
|kitv||XiXXu|

Some pa'al verbs have "a" as the vowel instead of "o" for the masculine singular imperative:

|Pronunciation| Example Verb| Pattern|
|:-----:|:------:|:------:|
|lm**a**d*||XX**a**X|
|limd|| XiXXi|
|limd||XiXXu|

*For consonant combinations that are hard to produce, a short "e" sound is introduced between the two consonants: l(e)mad.

For verbs with  as the final root consonant:

|Pronunciation| Example Verb| Pattern|
|:------:|:--------:|:--------:|
|kne| |XXeH|
|kni|  | XXi|
|knu|  | XXu|

Verbs with two root consonants, and irregular imperatives, are fairly variable. You will learn them as you go. Luckily most verbs have three root consonants. 

Pi'el Pattern
=========

|Pronunciation| Example Verb| Pattern|
|:------:|:--------:|:--------:|
|dabr| |XaXeX|
|dabr|  | XaXXi|
